____________________________________________________________

Incorporating Evidence-Based Ultrasound-Guided Vascular Access (USGVA) Standards Into the Nurse Anesthetist Armamentarium: A Quality Improvement Project

Author: Pitman, Jessica Szydlowski1; Buscemi, Michael1; Funk, Emily M1; Weaver, Shanna2; Thompson, Julie A1; Falyar, Christian31 Duke University School of Nursing, Durham, NC Jessica.szydlowski@duke.edu2 Department of Anesthesiology, University of North Carolina - Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, NC3 Middle Tennessee School of Anesthesia, Madison, TN

Publication info: Pitman, Jessica Szydlowski; Buscemi, Michael; Funk, Emily M; Weaver, Shanna; Thompson, Julie A; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/incorporating-evidence-based-ultrasound-guided/docview/2768240453/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: This quality improvement (QI) project developed and implemented a hybrid training program, that included online modules and hands-on training for experienced certified registered nurse anesthetists (CRNAs) to increase confidence, knowledge, and competency with ultrasound-guided vascular access (USGVA). PURPOSE This quality improvement (QI) project developed and implemented a hybrid training program, that included online modules and hands-on training for experienced certified registered nurse anesthetists (CRNAs) to increase confidence, knowledge, and competency with ultrasound-guided vascular access (USGVA).This QI project used a pre-post design. Seventeen volunteer CRNAs participated in USGVA training and education, and a 90-day follow-up assessment was performed. DESIGN This QI project used a pre-post design. Seventeen volunteer CRNAs participated in USGVA training and education, and a 90-day follow-up assessment was performed.The Revised Standards for Quality Improvement Reporting Excellence (SQUIRE 2.0) guidelines were used as a framework to assess confidence, knowledge, and hands-on competency of 17 CRNAs who regularly place vascular access devices using USGVA in patients with difficult vascular access at a single facility. These assessments were measured at: (1) baseline, (2) immediately after attending a hybrid training educational program, and (3) 90 days after implementation into clinical practice. Additionally, the number of vascular access attempts required for successful placement of peripheral intravenous (PIV) catheters, arterial catheters, and central venous catheters (CVC) with ultrasound assistance over a 90-day period was reviewed. METHODS The Revised Standards for Quality Improvement Reporting Excellence (SQUIRE 2.0) guidelines were used as a framework to assess confidence, knowledge, and hands-on competency of 17 CRNAs who regularly place vascular access devices using USGVA in patients with difficult vascular access at a single facility. These assessments were measured at: (1) baseline, (2) immediately after attending a hybrid training educational program, and (3) 90 days after implementation into clinical practice. Additionally, the number of vascular access attempts required for successful placement of peripheral intravenous (PIV) catheters, arterial catheters, and central venous catheters (CVC) with ultrasound assistance over a 90-day period was reviewed.Certified registered nurse anesthetists' median confidence score increased significantly from pre- to posteducation (P = .009). The confidence reported from post- to 90 days posteducation improved, however it did not reach statistical significance (P = .812). The knowledge scores from pre- to posteducation indicated significant improvement (P <. 001), as well as from pre- to 90 days posteducation (P = .03). However, knowledge scores from post- to 90 days posteducation revealed a statistically significant decline (P = .004). The overall median score for hands-on USGVA competency declined from post- to 90 days posteducation (P = .109). The number of successful USGVA placements increased from 50% to 80% within a 90-day period. FINDINGS Certified registered nurse anesthetists' median confidence score increased significantly from pre- to posteducation (P = .009). The confidence reported from post- to 90 days posteducation improved, however it did not reach statistical significance (P = .812). The knowledge scores from pre- to posteducation indicated significant improvement (P <. 001), as well as from pre- to 90 days posteducation (P = .03). However, knowledge scores from post- to 90 days posteducation revealed a statistically significant decline (P = .004). The overall median score for hands-on USGVA competency declined from post- to 90 days posteducation (P = .109). The number of successful USGVA placements increased from 50% to 80% within a 90-day period.The implementation of a USGVA hybrid training and education program improved overall provider confidence, knowledge, and competency. While confidence remained high in the 90-day follow-up, knowledge retention declined. Despite a decline in knowledge retention over time, results showed a significant improvement when compared to baseline scores. Although a decline in hands-on USGVA competency was seen at 90 days posteducation, it was not statistically significant. The percentage of overall successful USGVA placements in clinical practice increased following implementation. CONCLUSIONS The implementation of a USGVA hybrid training and education program improved overall provider confidence, knowledge, and competency. While confidence remained high in the 90-day follow-up, knowledge retention declined. Despite a decline in knowledge retention over time, results showed a significant improvement when compared to baseline scores. Although a decline in hands-on USGVA competency was seen at 90 days posteducation, it was not statistically significant. The percentage of overall successful USGVA placements in clinical practice increased following implementation.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Jessica&amp;aulast=Pitman&amp;atitle=Incorporating+Evidence-Based+Ultrasound-Guided+Vascular+Access+%28USGVA%29+Standards+Into+the+Nurse+Anesthetist+Armamentarium%3A+A+Quality+Improvement+Project&amp;stitle=Journal+of+perianesthesia+nursing+%3A+official+journal+of+the+American+Society+of+PeriAnesthesia+Nurses&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.jopan.2022.11.014&amp;title=Incorporating+Evidence-Based+Ultrasound-Guided+Vascular+Access+%28USGVA%29+Standards+Into+the+Nurse+Anesthetist+Armamentarium%3A+A+Quality+Improvement+Project&amp;volume=38&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=564&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Jessica&amp;aulast=Pitman&amp;atitle=Incorporating+Evidence-Based+Ultrasound-Guided+Vascular+Access+%28USGVA%29+Standards+Into+the+Nurse+Anesthetist+Armamentarium%3A+A+Quality+Improvement+Project&amp;stitle=Journal+of+perianesthesia+nursing+%3A+official+journal+of+the+American+Society+of+PeriAnesthesia+Nurses&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.jopan.2022.11.014&amp;title=Incorporating+Evidence-Based+Ultrasound-Guided+Vascular+Access+%28USGVA%29+Standards+Into+the+Nurse+Anesthetist+Armamentarium%3A+A+Quality+Improvement+Project&amp;volume=38&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=564&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

MeSH subject: Humans; Quality Improvement; Ultrasonography, Interventional -- methods; Nurse Anesthetists (major); Catheterization, Peripheral (major) -- methods

Supplemental data: Indexing method: Automated

Title: Incorporating Evidence-Based Ultrasound-Guided Vascular Access (USGVA) Standards Into the Nurse Anesthetist Armamentarium: A Quality Improvement Project

Improving Nursing Knowledge and Patient Education About Aprepitant's Effects on Hormonal Contraception: A Performance Improvement Project

Author: David, Ana Cecilia1; Pereira, Katherine1; Hartman, Emily2; Dear, Guy2; Thompson, Julie1; Funk, Emily31 Duke University School of Nursing, Durham, NC2 Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC3 Duke University School of Nursing, Durham, NC; Duke University Medical Center, Durham, NC emily.funk@duke.edu

Publication info: David, Ana Cecilia; Pereira, Katherine; Hartman, Emily; Dear, Guy; Thompson, Julie; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/improving-nursing-knowledge-patient-education/docview/2761182062/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: The purpose of this project was to improve the consistency of verbal and written discharge instructions for women of childbearing age (13-55 years) taking hormonal contraceptives who receive aprepitant perioperatively, to address the need to use a secondary form of birth control for 28 days, as well as to increase the knowledge and confidence of Registered Nurses when providing discharge instructions. PURPOSE The purpose of this project was to improve the consistency of verbal and written discharge instructions for women of childbearing age (13-55 years) taking hormonal contraceptives who receive aprepitant perioperatively, to address the need to use a secondary form of birth control for 28 days, as well as to increase the knowledge and confidence of Registered Nurses when providing discharge instructions.This quality improvement project used a pre-/postdesign to evaluate two separate groups of patients and registered nurses. DESIGN This quality improvement project used a pre-/postdesign to evaluate two separate groups of patients and registered nurses.The patient sample consisted of 30 total women of childbearing age who received aprepitant during the perioperative period (15 pre and 15 post). The PACU nurse sample included 15 ambulatory surgery center nurses and 58 main hospital nurses for a combined sample of 73 PACU nurses. The PACU nurses were provided with educational in-service regarding information about aprepitant and its drug interactions. PACU nurses were additionally instructed to provide patient discharge instructions using both a written and verbal format. Patients were called postoperatively before and after both the written after visit summary (AVS) changes and the PACU nurse in-services, PACU nurses were evaluated on their knowledge, confidence, and frequency of discharge teaching before and after their educational in-service. The PACU nurses were surveyed 90 days after the intervention to assess their long-term knowledge retention. METHODS The patient sample consisted of 30 total women of childbearing age who received aprepitant during the perioperative period (15 pre and 15 post). The PACU nurse sample included 15 ambulatory surgery center nurses and 58 main hospital nurses for a combined sample of 73 PACU nurses. The PACU nurses were provided with educational in-service regarding information about aprepitant and its drug interactions. PACU nurses were additionally instructed to provide patient discharge instructions using both a written and verbal format. Patients were called postoperatively before and after both the written after visit summary (AVS) changes and the PACU nurse in-services, PACU nurses were evaluated on their knowledge, confidence, and frequency of discharge teaching before and after their educational in-service. The PACU nurses were surveyed 90 days after the intervention to assess their long-term knowledge retention.There was a significant increase in nurse knowledge about aprepitant from preimplementation to postimplementation (61.39% vs 81.95%, P < .001). Nursing knowledge showed a nonsignificant decline at 90-days postimplementation (81.95% vs 73.68%, P = .096) although remained significantly higher than preimplementation scores (73.68% vs 61.39%, P = .003). There was an overall 33.3% increase in the percentage of patients who were able to recall receiving aprepitant and the need to use a secondary form of birth control when comparing the preintervention group to the postintervention group (26.7% vs 60%, P = .123). FINDINGS There was a significant increase in nurse knowledge about aprepitant from preimplementation to postimplementation (61.39% vs 81.95%, P < .001). Nursing knowledge showed a nonsignificant decline at 90-days postimplementation (81.95% vs 73.68%, P = .096) although remained significantly higher than preimplementation scores (73.68% vs 61.39%, P = .003). There was an overall 33.3% increase in the percentage of patients who were able to recall receiving aprepitant and the need to use a secondary form of birth control when comparing the preintervention group to the postintervention group (26.7% vs 60%, P = .123).The findings suggest that providing a standardized presentation about aprepitant may improve the PACU nurses' ability to verbalize key information about aprepitant, including the need for patients to use a secondary form of birth control. This increase in nursing knowledge and confidence, along with improved written discharge instructions, may have led to improved patient comprehension of aprepitant discharge education. Additionally, there was an increase in the percentage of patients who were able to recall the need to use a secondary form birth control for 28 days, to reduce the likelihood of an unintentional pregnancy. CONCLUSIONS The findings suggest that providing a standardized presentation about aprepitant may improve the PACU nurses' ability to verbalize key information about aprepitant, including the need for patients to use a secondary form of birth control. This increase in nursing knowledge and confidence, along with improved written discharge instructions, may have led to improved patient comprehension of aprepitant discharge education. Additionally, there was an increase in the percentage of patients who were able to recall the need to use a secondary form birth control for 28 days, to reduce the likelihood of an unintentional pregnancy.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Ana&amp;aulast=David&amp;atitle=Improving+Nursing+Knowledge+and+Patient+Education+About+Aprepitant%27s+Effects+on+Hormonal+Contraception%3A+A+Performance+Improvement+Project&amp;stitle=Journal+of+perianesthesia+nursing+%3A+official+journal+of+the+American+Society+of+PeriAnesthesia+Nurses&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.jopan.2022.09.008&amp;title=Improving+Nursing+Knowledge+and+Patient+Education+About+Aprepitant%27s+Effects+on+Hormonal+Contraception%3A+A+Performance+Improvement+Project&amp;volume=38&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=543&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Ana&amp;aulast=David&amp;atitle=Improving+Nursing+Knowledge+and+Patient+Education+About+Aprepitant%27s+Effects+on+Hormonal+Contraception%3A+A+Performance+Improvement+Project&amp;stitle=Journal+of+perianesthesia+nursing+%3A+official+journal+of+the+American+Society+of+PeriAnesthesia+Nurses&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.jopan.2022.09.008&amp;title=Improving+Nursing+Knowledge+and+Patient+Education+About+Aprepitant%27s+Effects+on+Hormonal+Contraception%3A+A+Performance+Improvement+Project&amp;volume=38&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=543&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

The Vision Detroit Project: Integrated Screening and Community Eye-Health Education Interventions Improve Eyecare Awareness

Author: Goyal, Anju1    ; Richards, Collin1    ; Freedman, Ryan L1    ; Rodriguez, Tannia1    ; Guest, John-Michael1; Patel, Vaama1; Syeda, Sarah1; Arsenault, Samantha M1; Kim, Chaesik1    ; Hall, Leo M1    ; Hughes, Bret A1; Juzych, Mark S1    1 Department of Ophthalmology, Visual, and Anatomical Sciences, Kresge Eye Institute, Wayne State University School of Medicine, Detroit, Michigan, USA

Publication info: Goyal, Anju; Richards, Collin; Freedman, Ryan L; Rodriguez, Tannia; Guest, John-Michael; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/vision-detroit-project-integrated-screening/docview/2720433453/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Poor eye-health knowledge and health literacy are pervasive, contributing to worse outcomes. This study aims to examine short- and long-term eye-health knowledge retention following eye-health education interventions in adults. PURPOSE Poor eye-health knowledge and health literacy are pervasive, contributing to worse outcomes. This study aims to examine short- and long-term eye-health knowledge retention following eye-health education interventions in adults.Vision Detroit was an outreach vision screening program that integrated a 5-Point Teaching Intervention (5PTI), at a Southwest Community Center (SW-CC) from 2015-2017. The 5PTI consists of eye-health learning points developed to verbally educate patients. During vision screenings, eye-health knowledge tests were administered before and after 5PTI (Test 1 and Test 2, respectively). In 2016, Community Eye-Health Education Interventions (CHEI) were initiated at the SW-CC. During CHEI, bilingual healthcare students taught voluntary SW-CC members the 5PTI learning points, regardless of participant interest to attend future screenings. CHEI sessions occurred on separate dates prior to vision screening events. Test 1 and Test 2 scores were compared for all participants. Test 1 scores were compared for those who underwent CHEI prior to vision screening (CHEI positive) versus those who did not (CHEI negative). METHODS Vision Detroit was an outreach vision screening program that integrated a 5-Point Teaching Intervention (5PTI), at a Southwest Community Center (SW-CC) from 2015-2017. The 5PTI consists of eye-health learning points developed to verbally educate patients. During vision screenings, eye-health knowledge tests were administered before and after 5PTI (Test 1 and Test 2, respectively). In 2016, Community Eye-Health Education Interventions (CHEI) were initiated at the SW-CC. During CHEI, bilingual healthcare students taught voluntary SW-CC members the 5PTI learning points, regardless of participant interest to attend future screenings. CHEI sessions occurred on separate dates prior to vision screening events. Test 1 and Test 2 scores were compared for all participants. Test 1 scores were compared for those who underwent CHEI prior to vision screening (CHEI positive) versus those who did not (CHEI negative).Two-hundred-seventeen adult patients met inclusion criteria, with 75.8% women, 82.6% Hispanic, mean age 50.4 ± 16.2 years, 74.6% had high school or less education, and 49.2% had health insurance. Test 1 to Test 2 scores improved after 5PTI (71.2 ± 26.4% vs. 97.2 ± 9.9%, p < .00001). Forty-eight participants attended CHEI and subsequent vision screening. Test 1 scores were higher among those CHEI positive versus CHEI negative (81.1 ± 2.1% vs. 68.3 ± 3.4%, p = .0027). RESULTS Two-hundred-seventeen adult patients met inclusion criteria, with 75.8% women, 82.6% Hispanic, mean age 50.4 ± 16.2 years, 74.6% had high school or less education, and 49.2% had health insurance. Test 1 to Test 2 scores improved after 5PTI (71.2 ± 26.4% vs. 97.2 ± 9.9%, p < .00001). Forty-eight participants attended CHEI and subsequent vision screening. Test 1 scores were higher among those CHEI positive versus CHEI negative (81.1 ± 2.1% vs. 68.3 ± 3.4%, p = .0027).Simple eye-health education interventions, delivered during vision screenings and via community-based education, can improve eye-health knowledge. CONCLUSION Simple eye-health education interventions, delivered during vision screenings and via community-based education, can improve eye-health knowledge.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Anju&amp;aulast=Goyal&amp;atitle=The+Vision+Detroit+Project%3A+Integrated+Screening+and+Community+Eye-Health+Education+Interventions+Improve+Eyecare+Awareness&amp;stitle=Ophthalmic+epidemiology&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1080%2F09286586.2022.2127785&amp;title=The+Vision+Detroit+Project%3A+Integrated+Screening+and+Community+Eye-Health+Education+Interventions+Improve+Eyecare+Awareness&amp;volume=30&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=367&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Anju&amp;aulast=Goyal&amp;atitle=The+Vision+Detroit+Project%3A+Integrated+Screening+and+Community+Eye-Health+Education+Interventions+Improve+Eyecare+Awareness&amp;stitle=Ophthalmic+epidemiology&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1080%2F09286586.2022.2127785&amp;title=The+Vision+Detroit+Project%3A+Integrated+Screening+and+Community+Eye-Health+Education+Interventions+Improve+Eyecare+Awareness&amp;volume=30&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=367&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Title: The Vision Detroit Project: Integrated Screening and Community Eye-Health Education Interventions Improve Eyecare Awareness

A Smartphone Application and Education Program for Hearing Health Promotion in High School Teenagers

Author: Chang, Jolie L1    ; Huwyler, Camille2    ; Yoshida, Norimasa3; Henderson Sabes, Jennifer2; Cheung, Steven W1    1 Department of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery, University of California, San Francisco, California, USA; Surgical Services, San Francisco Veterans Affairs Health Care System, San Francisco, California, USA2 Department of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery, University of California, San Francisco, California, USA3 Nori Consultants, Piedmont, California, USA

Publication info: Chang, Jolie L; Huwyler, Camille; Yoshida, Norimasa; Henderson Sabes, Jennifer; Cheung, Steven W. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/smartphone-application-education-program-hearing/docview/2718961423/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: To assess knowledge retention after video-based hearing health education and measure headphone listening behavior change using a novel smartphone application. OBJECTIVES To assess knowledge retention after video-based hearing health education and measure headphone listening behavior change using a novel smartphone application.In this prospective longitudinal study, students participated in video-based hearing health education and hearing screening sessions. Hearing health knowledge was assessed in students and parents after 6 weeks. A novel smartphone application was created to measure daily noise exposure based on volume settings with headphone use and to display the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) noise doses with alerts for cumulative daily doses nearing the maximum. METHODS In this prospective longitudinal study, students participated in video-based hearing health education and hearing screening sessions. Hearing health knowledge was assessed in students and parents after 6 weeks. A novel smartphone application was created to measure daily noise exposure based on volume settings with headphone use and to display the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) noise doses with alerts for cumulative daily doses nearing the maximum.Seventy-six teenage students and parents participated. Eighty three percent of participants identified as a racial or ethnic minority and 66% were of low-income socioeconomic status. Hearing health knowledge was retained in students 6 weeks after education and parents' knowledge improved from baseline. The smartphone app was installed on 12 student phones, and 25% of days monitored exhibited noise doses that exceeded the NIOSH maximum. App use for at least 10 days by nine students showed a significant reduction in average daily noise dose and time spent at the highest volume settings during the second-half of app use. RESULTS Seventy-six teenage students and parents participated. Eighty three percent of participants identified as a racial or ethnic minority and 66% were of low-income socioeconomic status. Hearing health knowledge was retained in students 6 weeks after education and parents' knowledge improved from baseline. The smartphone app was installed on 12 student phones, and 25% of days monitored exhibited noise doses that exceeded the NIOSH maximum. App use for at least 10 days by nine students showed a significant reduction in average daily noise dose and time spent at the highest volume settings during the second-half of app use.Video-based hearing health education with knowledge question reinforcement was associated with knowledge retention in students and improved parental attitudes and knowledge about hearing conservation. A smartphone app with a real-time display of headphone cumulative noise exposure dose identified at-risk students. The integration of hearing health education, hearing screening, and digital health tools has promised to promote positive behavior changes for long-term hearing conservation. CONCLUSIONS Video-based hearing health education with knowledge question reinforcement was associated with knowledge retention in students and improved parental attitudes and knowledge about hearing conservation. A smartphone app with a real-time display of headphone cumulative noise exposure dose identified at-risk students. The integration of hearing health education, hearing screening, and digital health tools has promised to promote positive behavior changes for long-term hearing conservation.4 Laryngoscope, 133:2007-2013, 2023. LEVEL OF EVIDENCE 4 Laryngoscope, 133:2007-2013, 2023.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Jolie&amp;aulast=Chang&amp;atitle=A+Smartphone+Application+and+Education+Program+for+Hearing+Health+Promotion+in+High+School+Teenagers&amp;stitle=The+Laryngoscope&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1002%2Flary.30411&amp;title=A+Smartphone+Application+and+Education+Program+for+Hearing+Health+Promotion+in+High+School+Teenagers&amp;volume=133&amp;issue=8&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=2007&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Supporting dyadic learning of English for tourism purposes with scenery-based virtual reality

Author: Lin, Vivien1    ; Barrett, Neil E.2; Liu, Gi-Zen3    ; Chen, Nian-Shing4; Jong, Morris Siu-Yung5    1 Graduate Institute of Children’s English, National Changhua University of Education, Changhua City, Taiwan vivienster@gmail.com2 English Language Center, Southern Taiwan University of Science & Technology, Tainan City, Taiwan baoneer@gmail.com3 Department of Foreign Languages & Literature, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan City, Taiwan gizen@mail.ncku.edu.tw4 Program of Learning Sciences, Institute for Research Excellence in Learning Science, National Taiwan Normal University, Taipei City, Taiwan nianshing@gmail.com5 Centre for Learning Sciences and Technologies, Department of Curriculum and Instruction, Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shatin, Hong Kong mjong@cuhk.edu.hk

Publication info: Lin, Vivien; Barrett, Neil E; Liu, Gi-Zen; Chen, Nian-Shing; Jong, Morris Siu-Yung. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/supporting-dyadic-learning-english-tourism/docview/2558138400/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: The field of language education has experienced a rise in using virtual reality (VR) to support interactive, contextualized, and collaborative language learning in recent years. The current study investigates the effects of auditory, visual, and textual input on speaking and writing in English for Tourism Purposes (ETP) through immersive, scenery-based virtual reality (SBVR) dyadic learning. Adopting a framework on ETP sociocultural, linguistic, and formulaic competence, the researchers designed relevant learning content using audios, images, and verbatim onscreen text on EduVenture VR to create an interactive, simulated tour. Thirty-eight English as a foreign language undergraduates participated in this single-group quasi-experiment. Various data sources included speaking and writing pre-, post- and delayed post-tests, a post-intervention survey, and reflections about the VR learning experience. The study reported significant speaking gains in language accuracy, destination promotion, knowledge retention, and replication of ETP language, as well as significant writing improvement in using sophisticated vocabulary, knowledge retention, and replication of ETP language. The study concludes that SBVR warrants positive impact on improving productive ETP skills. Possible factors, limitations, and pedagogical implications for using scenery-based VR in dyadic learning for ETP are discussed. Finally, the study suggests future research directions to combine technology-enhanced language learning theories with multimodal input and material design supported by immersive VR to enhance language production for specific purposes. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2023 APA, all rights reserved) (Source: journal abstract)

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Vivien&amp;aulast=Lin&amp;atitle=Supporting+dyadic+learning+of+English+for+tourism+purposes+with+scenery-based+virtual+reality&amp;stitle=Computer+Assisted+Language+Learning&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1080%2F09588221.2021.1954663&amp;title=Supporting+dyadic+learning+of+English+for+tourism+purposes+with+scenery-based+virtual+reality&amp;volume=36&amp;issue=5-6&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=906&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Vivien&amp;aulast=Lin&amp;atitle=Supporting+dyadic+learning+of+English+for+tourism+purposes+with+scenery-based+virtual+reality&amp;stitle=Computer+Assisted+Language+Learning&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1080%2F09588221.2021.1954663&amp;title=Supporting+dyadic+learning+of+English+for+tourism+purposes+with+scenery-based+virtual+reality&amp;volume=36&amp;issue=5-6&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=906&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Two-layer accumulated quantized compression for communication-efficient federated learning: TLAQC

Author: Ren, Yaoyao1; Cao, Yu1; Ye, Chengyin1; Cheng, Xu21 School of Information and Control Engineering, Liaoning Petrochemical University, Fushun, Liaoning, People's Republic of China caoyu@lnpu.edu.cn2 School of Economics and Management, Shenyang Agricultural University, Shengyang, Liaoning, People's Republic of China

Publication info: Ren, Yaoyao; Cao, Yu; Ye, Chengyin; Cheng, Xu. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/two-layer-accumulated-quantized-compression/docview/2840246149/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Federated learning enables multiple nodes to perform local computations and collaborate to complete machine learning tasks without centralizing private data of nodes. However, the frequent model gradients upload/download operations required by the framework result in high communication costs, which have become the main bottleneck for federated learning as deep models scale up, hindering its performance. In this paper, we propose a two-layer accumulated quantized compression algorithm (TLAQC) that effectively reduces the communication cost of federated learning. TLAQC achieves this by reducing both the cost of individual communication and the number of global communication rounds. TLAQC introduces a revised quantization method called RQSGD, which employs zero-value correction to mitigate ineffective quantization phenomena and minimize average quantization errors. Additionally, TLAQC reduces the frequency of gradient information uploads through an adaptive threshold and parameter self-inspection mechanism, further reducing communication costs. It also accumulates quantization errors and retained weight deltas to compensate for gradient knowledge loss. Through quantization correction and two-layer accumulation, TLAQC significantly reduces precision loss caused by communication compression. Experimental results demonstrate that RQSGD achieves an incidence of ineffective quantization as low as 0.003% and reduces the average quantization error to 1.6 × [Formula: see text]. Compared to full-precision FedAVG, TLAQC compresses uploaded traffic to only 6.73% while increasing accuracy by 1.25%.Federated learning enables multiple nodes to perform local computations and collaborate to complete machine learning tasks without centralizing private data of nodes. However, the frequent model gradients upload/download operations required by the framework result in high communication costs, which have become the main bottleneck for federated learning as deep models scale up, hindering its performance. In this paper, we propose a two-layer accumulated quantized compression algorithm (TLAQC) that effectively reduces the communication cost of federated learning. TLAQC achieves this by reducing both the cost of individual communication and the number of global communication rounds. TLAQC introduces a revised quantization method called RQSGD, which employs zero-value correction to mitigate ineffective quantization phenomena and minimize average quantization errors. Additionally, TLAQC reduces the frequency of gradient information uploads through an adaptive threshold and parameter self-inspection mechanism, further reducing communication costs. It also accumulates quantization errors and retained weight deltas to compensate for gradient knowledge loss. Through quantization correction and two-layer accumulation, TLAQC significantly reduces precision loss caused by communication compression. Experimental results demonstrate that RQSGD achieves an incidence of ineffective quantization as low as 0.003% and reduces the average quantization error to 1.6 × [Formula: see text]. Compared to full-precision FedAVG, TLAQC compresses uploaded traffic to only 6.73% while increasing accuracy by 1.25%.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Yaoyao&amp;aulast=Ren&amp;atitle=Two-layer+accumulated+quantized+compression+for+communication-efficient+federated+learning%3A+TLAQC&amp;stitle=Scientific+reports&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1038%2Fs41598-023-38916-x&amp;title=Two-layer+accumulated+quantized+compression+for+communication-efficient+federated+learning%3A+TLAQC&amp;volume=13&amp;issue=1&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=11658&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Child restraint systems: Understanding confidence in proper use and addressing the need for education

Author: Britton, Jennifer; Jacobs, Kaitlyn https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0203-455X; Haidar, Tania; Stolworthy, Christopher; Armstrong, Alison; Merritt, Neil https://orcid.org/0000-0003-1310-6114; Parry, Neil; Vogt, Kelly; Priestap, Fran https://orcid.org/0000-0002-5766-4532

Publication info: Britton, Jennifer; Jacobs, Kaitlyn https://orcid.org/0000-0002-0203-455X; Haidar, Tania; Stolworthy, Christopher; Armstrong, Alison; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/child-restraint-systems-understanding-confidence/docview/3040350779/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: ENG English ENG To quantify the extent of proper local child restraint system (CRS) use and to better understand changes to the level of self-reported confidence with increased CRS installations. With the goal being to improve safety for children travelling in personal vehicles across London, ON and the region. Public CRS clinics were initiated by Injury Prevention staff after they obtained the Child Passenger Safety Technician certification. Additionally, an online survey was commissioned targeting Ontario parents who had installed at least one CRS in the last five years. From September 2018 to September 2019, 96 comprehensive CRS checks were performed, with 29% of systems found to be installed correctly. Survey results showed a high level of reported confidence with CRS installation (N = 514, 70% female, 43% one child). Parents who had installed only one CRS reported higher confidence in their first install, compared to parents who had installed two or more systems. The error rate with CRS installation and use seen in London, Ontario and the region, is similar to that reported in previous research. Survey results showed high levels of self-reported confidence in CRS use, especially for parents who have installed only one CRS. There presents a need to better understand the root cause of the discrepancy between level of confidence and proper CRS use and to expand our understanding of CRS knowledge retention and transferability to subsequent systems.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Jennifer&amp;aulast=Britton&amp;atitle=Child+restraint+systems%3A+Understanding+confidence+in+proper+use+and+addressing+the+need+for+education&amp;stitle=Heliyon&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.heliyon.2023.e17409&amp;title=Child+restraint+systems%3A+Understanding+confidence+in+proper+use+and+addressing+the+need+for+education&amp;volume=9&amp;issue=7+p.e17409-&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Jennifer&amp;aulast=Britton&amp;atitle=Child+restraint+systems%3A+Understanding+confidence+in+proper+use+and+addressing+the+need+for+education&amp;stitle=Heliyon&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.heliyon.2023.e17409&amp;title=Child+restraint+systems%3A+Understanding+confidence+in+proper+use+and+addressing+the+need+for+education&amp;volume=9&amp;issue=7+p.e17409-&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Evidence-Based Practice Knowledge Retention Among Nurse Practitioner Students

Author: Young, Cara C; Danesh, Valerie; De Main Atami S; Sales, Adam C

Publication info: Young, Cara C; Danesh, Valerie; De Main Atami S; Sales, Adam C. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/evidence-based-practice-knowledge-retention-among/docview/2880769908/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: The mastery of clinical scholarship and analytic methods for evidence-based practice (EBP) is a published essential for nurse practitioner (NP) education; however, retention of EBP-related knowledge during NP education remains unknown. We assessed EBP knowledge during a first-semester research course and again during the last semester using an item response model. We found that changes depended on the exam item, with performance dropping on a third of the items. Our findings suggest a need to integrate EBP concepts across curricula (e.g., feedback loops in courses other than the research course) to retain these essential skills.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Cara&amp;aulast=Young&amp;atitle=Evidence-Based+Practice+Knowledge+Retention+Among+Nurse+Practitioner+Students&amp;stitle=Nursing+Education+Perspectives&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1097%2F01.NEP.0000000000001064&amp;title=Evidence-Based+Practice+Knowledge+Retention+Among+Nurse+Practitioner+Students&amp;volume=44&amp;issue=4&amp;date=Jul-Aug+2023&amp;spage=244&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Examination performance with flipped classroom as instructional strategy in the carbohydrate metabolism course unit at a Philippine medical school: Estimation of average treatment effect from observational data

Author: Michael Van Haute1    ; Monzon, Jan David11 Department of Biochemistry, De La Salle Medical and Health Sciences Institute–College of Medicine, Dasmariñas, Philippines

Publication info: Michael Van Haute; Monzon, Jan David. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/examination-performance-with-flipped-classroom-as/docview/2847558798/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: While the innovativeness of the flipped classroom (FC) approach promotes active participation and higher‐order thinking among students, there are concerns about its effectiveness in terms of knowledge retention. Currently, there are no studies involving medical school biochemistry that evaluate this aspect of effectiveness. Thus, we conducted a historical control study that analyzed observational data from two freshman batches of the Doctor of Medicine program in our institution. Class 2021 ( n  = 250) served as the traditional lecture (TL) group while Class 2022 ( n  = 264) served as the FC group. Data on relevant observed covariates (age, sex, National Medical Admission Test or NMAT score, undergraduate degree) and the outcome variable (carbohydrate metabolism course unit examination percentage scores, as indicator of knowledge retention) were included in the analysis. Propensity scores were calculated using logit regression conditional on these observed covariates. Afterwards, 1:1 nearest‐neighbor propensity score matching (PSM) was performed to produce an estimated average treatment effect (ATE) measure afforded by FC (as adjusted mean difference in examination scores between the two batches), balancing on the covariates. Nearest‐neighbor matching using the calculated propensity scores effectively balanced the two groups (standardized bias <10%), producing 250 matched student‐pairs that received either TL or FC. Following PSM, the FC group was found to have a significantly higher adjusted mean examination score compared to the TL group (adjusted mean difference = 5.62%, 95% CI: 2.54%, 8.72%; p  < 0.001). Using this approach, we were able to demonstrate benefit of FC over TL in terms of knowledge retention, as reflected by the estimated ATE.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Michael+Van+Haute&amp;atitle=Examination+performance+with+flipped+classroom+as+instructional+strategy+in+the+carbohydrate+metabolism+course+unit+at+a+Philippine+medical+school%3A+Estimation+of+average+treatment+effect+from+observational+data&amp;stitle=Biochemistry+and+Molecular+Biology+Education&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1002%2Fbmb.21740&amp;title=Examination+performance+with+flipped+classroom+as+instructional+strategy+in+the+carbohydrate+metabolism+course+unit+at+a+Philippine+medical+school%3A+Estimation+of+average+treatment+effect+from+observational+data&amp;volume=51&amp;issue=4&amp;date=Jul%2FAug+2023&amp;spage=428&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Michael+Van+Haute&amp;atitle=Examination+performance+with+flipped+classroom+as+instructional+strategy+in+the+carbohydrate+metabolism+course+unit+at+a+Philippine+medical+school%3A+Estimation+of+average+treatment+effect+from+observational+data&amp;stitle=Biochemistry+and+Molecular+Biology+Education&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1002%2Fbmb.21740&amp;title=Examination+performance+with+flipped+classroom+as+instructional+strategy+in+the+carbohydrate+metabolism+course+unit+at+a+Philippine+medical+school%3A+Estimation+of+average+treatment+effect+from+observational+data&amp;volume=51&amp;issue=4&amp;date=Jul%2FAug+2023&amp;spage=428&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Key topicsPowered by Web of Science® Description for Powered by Web of Science: Average treatment effect; Medical school; Flipped classroom; Classroom; Knowledge management

ERIC Subject: Retention (Psychology); Flipped Classroom; Admission Criteria; Metabolism; Teaching Methods; School Holding Power; Educational Strategies

Subject: Tests; Metabolism; Teaching methods; Flipped classroom; Academic achievement; Carbohydrate metabolism

Identifier / keyword: examination performance; Average treatment effect; Medical school; Flipped classroom; Classroom; Knowledge management; flipped classroom; knowledge retention; medical school biochemistry; propensity score matching

Title: Examination performance with flipped classroom as instructional strategy in the carbohydrate metabolism course unit at a Philippine medical school: Estimation of average treatment effect from observational data

Publication title: Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Education; Calgary

Child restraint systems: Understanding confidence in proper use and addressing the need for education

Author: Britton, Jennifer1; Jacobs, Kaitlyn1; Haidar, Tania1; Stolworthy, Christopher1; Armstrong, Alison1; Merritt, Neil1; Parry, Neil1; Vogt, Kelly1; Priestap, Fran11 London Health Sciences Centre - Trauma Program 800 Commissioners Road East London, ON N6A 5W9, Canada

Publication info: Britton, Jennifer; Jacobs, Kaitlyn; Haidar, Tania; Stolworthy, Christopher; Armstrong, Alison; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/child-restraint-systems-understanding-confidence/docview/2844088358/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: To quantify the extent of proper local child restraint system (CRS) use and to better understand changes to the level of self-reported confidence with increased CRS installations. With the goal being to improve safety for children travelling in personal vehicles across London, ON and the region. Objective To quantify the extent of proper local child restraint system (CRS) use and to better understand changes to the level of self-reported confidence with increased CRS installations. With the goal being to improve safety for children travelling in personal vehicles across London, ON and the region.Public CRS clinics were initiated by Injury Prevention staff after they obtained the Child Passenger Safety Technician certification. Additionally, an online survey was commissioned targeting Ontario parents who had installed at least one CRS in the last five years. Methods Public CRS clinics were initiated by Injury Prevention staff after they obtained the Child Passenger Safety Technician certification. Additionally, an online survey was commissioned targeting Ontario parents who had installed at least one CRS in the last five years.From September 2018 to September 2019, 96 comprehensive CRS checks were performed, with 29% of systems found to be installed correctly. Survey results showed a high level of reported confidence with CRS installation (N = 514, 70% female, 43% one child). Parents who had installed only one CRS reported higher confidence in their first install, compared to parents who had installed two or more systems. Results From September 2018 to September 2019, 96 comprehensive CRS checks were performed, with 29% of systems found to be installed correctly. Survey results showed a high level of reported confidence with CRS installation (N = 514, 70% female, 43% one child). Parents who had installed only one CRS reported higher confidence in their first install, compared to parents who had installed two or more systems.The error rate with CRS installation and use seen in London, Ontario and the region, is similar to that reported in previous research. Survey results showed high levels of self-reported confidence in CRS use, especially for parents who have installed only one CRS. There presents a need to better understand the root cause of the discrepancy between level of confidence and proper CRS use and to expand our understanding of CRS knowledge retention and transferability to subsequent systems. Conclusions The error rate with CRS installation and use seen in London, Ontario and the region, is similar to that reported in previous research. Survey results showed high levels of self-reported confidence in CRS use, especially for parents who have installed only one CRS. There presents a need to better understand the root cause of the discrepancy between level of confidence and proper CRS use and to expand our understanding of CRS knowledge retention and transferability to subsequent systems.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Jennifer&amp;aulast=Britton&amp;atitle=Child+restraint+systems%3A+Understanding+confidence+in+proper+use+and+addressing+the+need+for+education&amp;stitle=Heliyon&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.heliyon.2023.e17409&amp;title=Child+restraint+systems%3A+Understanding+confidence+in+proper+use+and+addressing+the+need+for+education&amp;volume=9&amp;issue=7&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=e17409&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Jennifer&amp;aulast=Britton&amp;atitle=Child+restraint+systems%3A+Understanding+confidence+in+proper+use+and+addressing+the+need+for+education&amp;stitle=Heliyon&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.heliyon.2023.e17409&amp;title=Child+restraint+systems%3A+Understanding+confidence+in+proper+use+and+addressing+the+need+for+education&amp;volume=9&amp;issue=7&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=e17409&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Amanda&amp;aulast=McCullough&amp;atitle=Lyrics+for+Learning%3A+Using+Song+to+Improve+Knowledge+Retention&amp;stitle=The+Journal+of+nursing+education&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.3928%2F01484834-20230509-07&amp;title=Lyrics+for+Learning%3A+Using+Song+to+Improve+Knowledge+Retention&amp;volume=62&amp;issue=7&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=427&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Lyrics for Learning: Using Song to Improve Knowledge Retention

Author: Pepper, Margaret11 University of Mississippi Medical Center, School of Nursing

Publication info: Pepper, Margaret. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/lyrics-learning-using-song-improve-knowledge/docview/2833717585/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Using the conceptual knowledge dimension of Bloom's taxonomy of education objectives in the development of this learning activity, a flipped-classroom approach was used for second-semester undergraduate baccalaureate students in an attempt to bridge the gap between classroom and clinical settings (Phillips, 2020). Evidence has shown that musical formats promote information recall in learning new material (Werner, 2018). [...]the question was asked, “Can song promote knowledge retention regarding safe medication administration, as well as pertinent information regarding patient monitoring and education?” Prior to traditional classroom teaching, students were required to review the prepared PowerPoint® lectures and assigned reading materials regarding neurologic medications. Quantitative and qualitative data collection and analyses may support the use of this teaching strategy to fully recognize its effects on knowledge retention.

Application of Knowledge Management Components from the Faculty Members' Perspective at Iran University of Medical Sciences Research Centers

Author: Nemati-Anaraki, Leila1; Hassanzadeh, Hossain1; Panahi, Sirous1; Malgard, Shiva11 Department of Medical Library and Information Sciences, School of Health Management and Information Sciences, Iran University of Medical Sciences, Tehran, Iran

Publication info: Nemati-Anaraki, Leila; Hassanzadeh, Hossain; Panahi, Sirous; Malgard, Shiva. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/application-knowledge-management-components/docview/2833247021/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Knowledge management is critical for universities and research institutes to improve their operations and activities. The study aimed to investigate knowledge management components in Iran University of Medical Sciences research centers from the faculty members' perspective. The sample size for the present study was generated using a simple random approach and Cochran's formula. The sample size was 245 out of 673 associate faculty members in affiliated research centers of the Iran University of Medical Sciences. The research instrument was the Fong and Choi knowledge management standard questionnaire. Following data collection, SPSS software version 23 was used to analyze the data using descriptive statistics and Pearson correlation tests. From the participant's perspective, the results indicated that the status of knowledge acquisition components was relatively good, with an average of 3.26, knowledge creation at 3.42, knowledge storage at 3.19, knowledge distribution at 3.13, knowledge application at 3.34, and knowledge retention at 3.24. According to respondents, there was an inverse statistical relationship between knowledge generation and application components and the research ranking of research centers and a direct statistical relationship between knowledge storage and retention (P-value 0.05). According to the findings, knowledge management components were applied effectively in research institutions affiliated with the Iran University of Medical Sciences. As a result, planning and strategies at research institutions and universities are required to raise this level to the desired level.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Leila&amp;aulast=Nemati-Anaraki&amp;atitle=Application+of+Knowledge+Management+Components+from+the+Faculty+Members%27+Perspective+at+Iran+University+of+Medical+Sciences+Research+Centers&amp;stitle=International+Journal+of+Information+Science+and+Management&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.22034%2Fijism.2023.1977793.0&amp;title=Application+of+Knowledge+Management+Components+from+the+Faculty+Members%27+Perspective+at+Iran+University+of+Medical+Sciences+Research+Centers&amp;volume=21&amp;issue=3&amp;date=Jul-Sep+2023&amp;spage=243&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Leila&amp;aulast=Nemati-Anaraki&amp;atitle=Application+of+Knowledge+Management+Components+from+the+Faculty+Members%27+Perspective+at+Iran+University+of+Medical+Sciences+Research+Centers&amp;stitle=International+Journal+of+Information+Science+and+Management&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.22034%2Fijism.2023.1977793.0&amp;title=Application+of+Knowledge+Management+Components+from+the+Faculty+Members%27+Perspective+at+Iran+University+of+Medical+Sciences+Research+Centers&amp;volume=21&amp;issue=3&amp;date=Jul-Sep+2023&amp;spage=243&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Escaping the cell: virtual reality escape rooms in biology education

Author: Christopoulos, Athanasios1    ; Mystakidis, Stylianos2; Cachafeiro, Enrique3    ; Laakso, Mikko-Jussi41 Fac ulty of Science, Centre for Learning Analytics, University of Turku, Turku, Finland2 School of Natural Sciences, University of Patras, Patras, Greece; School of Humanities, Hellenic Open University, Patras, Greece3 OESO, Duke Health, Durham, NC, USA4 Faculty of Technology, Department of Computing, University of Turku, Turku, Finland

Publication info: Christopoulos, Athanasios; Mystakidis, Stylianos; Cachafeiro, Enrique; Laakso, Mikko-Jussi. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/escaping-cell-virtual-reality-escape-rooms/docview/2829578897/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Individuals’ conceptual knowledge of contemporary biological issues influences ethical attitudes and life decisions around health, as evidenced by the recent worldwide debate on vaccinations. The reasons for which the public opinion is so critically divided can be partially explained from the didactic approaches used in biology education. In view of the rapid evolution of Virtual Reality (VR) as well as the increasing interest that youths have shown toward Escape Rooms (ER), an unexplored research and development avenue is identified. In this experimental study, we present the design and development steps as well as the evaluation of a VRER dedicated to biology education. For comparison purposes, an educational instructional video utilising the storytelling technique was also prepared. Both approaches were examined in the upper secondary education context with participants ( N  = 50) emerging from the Applied Sciences academic path. The key-findings suggest that the active learning approach leads to increased knowledge acquisition, in the short term, as opposed to the passive learning approach but no significant differences were identified in the long term (knowledge retention) across the methods. Based on the instructional decisions made and the key-findings emerged we provide implications and guidelines for the design, development, and integration of VRER in education.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Athanasios&amp;aulast=Christopoulos&amp;atitle=Escaping+the+cell%3A+virtual+reality+escape+rooms+in+biology+education&amp;stitle=Behaviour+%26+Information+Technology&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1080%2F0144929X.2022.2079560&amp;title=Escaping+the+cell%3A+virtual+reality+escape+rooms+in+biology+education&amp;volume=42&amp;issue=9&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=1434&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Athanasios&amp;aulast=Christopoulos&amp;atitle=Escaping+the+cell%3A+virtual+reality+escape+rooms+in+biology+education&amp;stitle=Behaviour+%26+Information+Technology&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1080%2F0144929X.2022.2079560&amp;title=Escaping+the+cell%3A+virtual+reality+escape+rooms+in+biology+education&amp;volume=42&amp;issue=9&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=1434&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Managing knowledge loss: a systematic literature review and future research directions

Author: Daghfous, Abdelkader1    ; Noha Tarek Amer2; Belkhodja, Omar3; Angell, Linda C1    ; Zoubi, Taisier41 Department of Marketing and Information Systems, American University of Sharjah, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates2 Tuangru Holdings Inc, Vancouver, Canada3 Department of Management, American University of Sharjah, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates4 Department of Accounting, American University of Sharjah, Sharjah, United Arab Emi rates

Publication info: Daghfous, Abdelkader; Noha Tarek Amer; Belkhodja, Omar; Angell, Linda C; Zoubi, Taisier. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/managing-knowledge-loss-xa0-systematic-literature/docview/2824601368/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Purpose Job market shifts, such as workforce mobility and aging societies, cause the exit of knowledgeable personnel from organizations. The ensuing knowledge loss (K-loss) has broad negative effects. This study analyzes the knowledge management literature on K-loss published from 2000 to 2021 and identifies fruitful directions for future research. Design/methodology/approach The authors conduct a systematic literature review of 74 peer-reviewed articles published between 2000 and 2021. These articles were retrieved from ProQuest Central, Science Direct, EBSCOhost and Emerald databases. The analysis utilizes Jesson et al .’s (2011) six principles: field mapping, comprehensive search, quality assessment, data extraction, synthesis and write-up. Findings Three sub-topics emerge from the systematic literature review: K-loss drivers, positive and negative impacts of K-loss and mitigation strategies. Over half of the literature addresses mitigation strategies and provides solutions for K-loss already in progress, rather than proposing preventive measures. Research limitations/implications This study has limitations related to the time span covered. Moreover, it focuses on articles published in refereed journals. Therefore, important contributions from conference papers, books and professional reports were excluded. Originality/value This research comprehensively synthesizes the K-loss literature and proposes future avenues of research to address under-investigated areas and potentially lead to theoretical and empirical advancements in the field. This study also provides suggestions for improving managerial practices.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Abdelkader&amp;aulast=Daghfous&amp;atitle=Managing+knowledge+loss%3A+a%26nbsp%3Bsystematic+literature+review+and%26nbsp%3Bfuture+research+directions&amp;stitle=Journal+of+Enterprise+Information+Management&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1108%2FJEIM-05-2022-0171&amp;title=Managing+knowledge+loss%3A+a%26%23xa0%3Bsystematic+literature+review+and%26%23xa0%3Bfuture+research+directions&amp;volume=36&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=1008&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Abdelkader&amp;aulast=Daghfous&amp;atitle=Managing+knowledge+loss%3A+a%26nbsp%3Bsystematic+literature+review+and%26nbsp%3Bfuture+research+directions&amp;stitle=Journal+of+Enterprise+Information+Management&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1108%2FJEIM-05-2022-0171&amp;title=Managing+knowledge+loss%3A+a%26%23xa0%3Bsystematic+literature+review+and%26%23xa0%3Bfuture+research+directions&amp;volume=36&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=1008&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Key topicsPowered by Web of Science® Description for Powered by Web of Science: Knowledge; Systematic review; Knowledge management; Managing

Subject: Research; Quality assessment; Journals; Human resource management; Tacit knowledge; Knowledge sharing; Employment; Pandemics; Data search; Knowledge management; Workforce; Resignations; Retention; Employee turnover; Operations management; Literature reviews; Empirical analysis; Layoffs; Systematic review; Product development; Books; Databases; Future; Research design; Mapping; Data quality; Knowledge; Literary criticism; Labor market; Extraction; Prevention programs; Research methodology; Mobility; Mitigation; Aging

Generational knowledge transfer and retention strategies

Author: Cox , Victoria1; Overbey, Julie A11 University of Phoenix, Phoenix, Arizona, USA

Publication info: Cox, Victoria; Overbey, Julie A. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/generational-knowledge-transfer-retention/docview/2821655819/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Purpose This study reviews strategies organizational leaders and human resource practitioners can deploy to develop knowledge transfer and retention succession planning strategies for older employees to mitigate generational organizational knowledge loss prior to retirement. Design/methodology/approach This study used a questionnaire with 28 baby boomer employees and leaders of baby boomers at a large federal agency. Purposive and snowball sampling techniques were used. Questions asked participants about knowledge transfer, retention strategies and how challenges to counter baby boomer knowledge loss are addressed in the workplace. Findings Develop succession plans using standard operating procedures and job aids to reduce knowledge loss and enhance retention. Deploy hands-on training to share historical knowledge, enhance relationship building, mentoring programs, cross-training opportunities, retention incentives and document process improvement. The strategies are supported by organizational learning and knowledge management theories. Originality/value This study contributes to organizational leaders’ and human resource practitioners’ knowledge transfer and retention succession planning strategies to counter generational knowledge loss.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Victoria&amp;aulast=Cox&amp;atitle=Generational+knowledge+transfer+and+retention+strategies&amp;stitle=Development+and+Learning+in+Organizations&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1108%2FDLO-03-2022-0055&amp;title=Generational+knowledge+transfer+and+retention+strategies&amp;volume=37&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=10&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Victoria&amp;aulast=Cox&amp;atitle=Generational+knowledge+transfer+and+retention+strategies&amp;stitle=Development+and+Learning+in+Organizations&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1108%2FDLO-03-2022-0055&amp;title=Generational+knowledge+transfer+and+retention+strategies&amp;volume=37&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=10&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Examination performance with flipped classroom as instructional strategy in the carbohydrate metabolism course unit at a Philippine medical school: Estimation of average treatment effect from observational data

Author: Van Haute, Michael1    ; Monzon, Jan David11 Department of Biochemistry, De La Salle Medical and Health Sciences Institute-College of Medicine, Dasmariñas, Philippines

Publication info: Van Haute, Michael; Monzon, Jan David. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/examination-performance-with-flipped-classroom-as/docview/2810919240/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: While the innovativeness of the flipped classroom (FC) approach promotes active participation and higher-order thinking among students, there are concerns about its effectiveness in terms of knowledge retention. Currently, there are no studies involving medical school biochemistry that evaluate this aspect of effectiveness. Thus, we conducted a historical control study that analyzed observational data from two freshman batches of the Doctor of Medicine program in our institution. Class 2021 (n = 250) served as the traditional lecture (TL) group while Class 2022 (n = 264) served as the FC group. Data on relevant observed covariates (age, sex, National Medical Admission Test or NMAT score, undergraduate degree) and the outcome variable (carbohydrate metabolism course unit examination percentage scores, as indicator of knowledge retention) were included in the analysis. Propensity scores were calculated using logit regression conditional on these observed covariates. Afterwards, 1:1 nearest-neighbor propensity score matching (PSM) was performed to produce an estimated average treatment effect (ATE) measure afforded by FC (as adjusted mean difference in examination scores between the two batches), balancing on the covariates. Nearest-neighbor matching using the calculated propensity scores effectively balanced the two groups (standardized bias <10%), producing 250 matched student-pairs that received either TL or FC. Following PSM, the FC group was found to have a significantly higher adjusted mean examination score compared to the TL group (adjusted mean difference = 5.62%, 95% CI: 2.54%, 8.72%; p < 0.001). Using this approach, we were able to demonstrate benefit of FC over TL in terms of knowledge retention, as reflected by the estimated ATE.While the innovativeness of the flipped classroom (FC) approach promotes active participation and higher-order thinking among students, there are concerns about its effectiveness in terms of knowledge retention. Currently, there are no studies involving medical school biochemistry that evaluate this aspect of effectiveness. Thus, we conducted a historical control study that analyzed observational data from two freshman batches of the Doctor of Medicine program in our institution. Class 2021 (n = 250) served as the traditional lecture (TL) group while Class 2022 (n = 264) served as the FC group. Data on relevant observed covariates (age, sex, National Medical Admission Test or NMAT score, undergraduate degree) and the outcome variable (carbohydrate metabolism course unit examination percentage scores, as indicator of knowledge retention) were included in the analysis. Propensity scores were calculated using logit regression conditional on these observed covariates. Afterwards, 1:1 nearest-neighbor propensity score matching (PSM) was performed to produce an estimated average treatment effect (ATE) measure afforded by FC (as adjusted mean difference in examination scores between the two batches), balancing on the covariates. Nearest-neighbor matching using the calculated propensity scores effectively balanced the two groups (standardized bias <10%), producing 250 matched student-pairs that received either TL or FC. Following PSM, the FC group was found to have a significantly higher adjusted mean examination score compared to the TL group (adjusted mean difference = 5.62%, 95% CI: 2.54%, 8.72%; p < 0.001). Using this approach, we were able to demonstrate benefit of FC over TL in terms of knowledge retention, as reflected by the estimated ATE.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Michael&amp;aulast=Van+Haute&amp;atitle=Examination+performance+with+flipped+classroom+as+instructional+strategy+in+the+carbohydrate+metabolism+course+unit+at+a+Philippine+medical+school%3A+Estimation+of+average+treatment+effect+from+observational+data&amp;stitle=Biochemistry+and+molecular+biology+education+%3A+a+bimonthly+publication+of+the+International+Union+of+Biochemistry+and+Molecular+Biology&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1002%2Fbmb.21740&amp;title=Examination+performance+with+flipped+classroom+as+instructional+strategy+in+the+carbohydrate+metabolism+course+unit+at+a+Philippine+medical+school%3A+Estimation+of+average+treatment+effect+from+observational+data&amp;volume=51&amp;issue=4&amp;date=Jul-Aug+2023&amp;spage=428&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

The Great Resignation: the great knowledge exodus or the onset of the Great Knowledge Revolution?

Author: Serenko, Alexander11 Alexander Serenko is based at the Faculty of Business and IT, University of Ontario Institute of Technology, Oshawa, Canada

Publication info: Serenko, Alexander. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/great-resignation-knowledge-exodus-onset/docview/2792369030/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Purpose The purpose of this Real Impact Viewpoint Article is to analyze the phenomenon of the Great Resignation from the knowledge management perspective. Design/methodology/approach It applies the knowledge-based view of the firm to the notion of the Great Resignation, reviews the extant literature and relies on secondary data. Findings The Great Resignation has created numerous knowledge-related impacts on the individual, organizational and national levels. On the individual level, because of an accelerating adoption of freelancing, the future may witness an expansion of the category of the knowledge worker and a growing need for personal knowledge management methods and information technologies. Organizational effects include knowledge loss, reduced business process efficiency, damaged intra-organizational knowledge flows, lower relational capital, lost informal friendship networks, difficulty attracting the best human capital, undermined knowledge transfer processes and knowledge leakage to competition. Countries may also witness the depletion of national human capital. Practical implications Managers should learn how to use the available human capital more efficiently; realize the importance of universal succession planning programs; automate knowledge-centric business processes; facilitate knowledge-based IT initiatives by implementing self-functioning virtual communities, including enterprise social networks; restructure organizations to optimize intra-organizational knowledge flows; adjust strategies, products and target markets based on the available human capital; and create telecommuting conditions for people with disabilities who cannot be physically present. Knowledge management scholars are presented with a unique opportunity to convert the numerous theoretical insights accumulated within the boundaries of their discipline into practical application to facilitate the Great Knowledge Revolution. Originality/value This viewpoint offers managerial recommendations and inspires future Great Resignation investigations.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Alexander&amp;aulast=Serenko&amp;atitle=The+Great+Resignation%3A+the+great+knowledge+exodus+or+the+onset+of+the+Great+Knowledge+Revolution%3F&amp;stitle=Journal+of+Knowledge+Management&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1108%2FJKM-12-2021-0920&amp;title=The+Great+Resignation%3A+the+great+knowledge+exodus+or+the+onset+of+the+Great+Knowledge+Revolution%3F&amp;volume=27&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=1042&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=unknown&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Alexander&amp;aulast=Serenko&amp;atitle=The+Great+Resignation%3A+the+great+knowledge+exodus+or+the+onset+of+the+Great+Knowledge+Revolution%3F&amp;stitle=Journal+of+Knowledge+Management&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1108%2FJKM-12-2021-0920&amp;title=The+Great+Resignation%3A+the+great+knowledge+exodus+or+the+onset+of+the+Great+Knowledge+Revolution%3F&amp;volume=27&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=1042&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=unknown&amp;

Key topicsPowered by Web of Science® Description for Powered by Web of Science: Knowledge management; Knowledge economy; Knowledge transfer; Revolution

Evidence-Based Practice Knowledge Retention Among Nurse Practitioner Students

Author: Young, Cara C1; Danesh, Valerie; De Main, Atami S; Sales, Adam C1 About the Authors Cara C. Young, PhD, APRN, FNP-C, FAANP, is an associate professor, School of Nursing, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, Texas. Valerie Danesh, PhD, RN, FCCM, is a research scientist, Center for Applied Health Research, Baylor Scott & White Health, Dallas, Texas. Atami S. De Main, MHS, RN, is a PhD student, School of Nursing, University of Texas at Austin. Adam C. Sales, PhD, is an assistant professor, Mathematical Sciences Department, Worcester Polytechnic Institute, Worcester, Massachusetts. Editorial support was provided by the Cain Center for Nursing Research and the Center for Transdisciplinary Collaborative Research in Self-Management Science (P30, NR015335) at the University of Texas at Austin. For more information, contact Dr. Danesh at Valerie.Danesh@BSWHealth.org

Publication info: Young, Cara C; Danesh, Valerie; De Main, Atami S; Sales, Adam C. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/evidence-based-practice-knowledge-retention-among/docview/2725201947/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: The mastery of clinical scholarship and analytic methods for evidence-based practice (EBP) is a published essential for nurse practitioner (NP) education; however, retention of EBP-related knowledge during NP education remains unknown. We assessed EBP knowledge during a first-semester research course and again during the last semester using an item response model. We found that changes depended on the exam item, with performance dropping on a third of the items. Our findings suggest a need to integrate EBP concepts across curricula (e.g., feedback loops in courses other than the research course) to retain these essential skills. ABSTRACT The mastery of clinical scholarship and analytic methods for evidence-based practice (EBP) is a published essential for nurse practitioner (NP) education; however, retention of EBP-related knowledge during NP education remains unknown. We assessed EBP knowledge during a first-semester research course and again during the last semester using an item response model. We found that changes depended on the exam item, with performance dropping on a third of the items. Our findings suggest a need to integrate EBP concepts across curricula (e.g., feedback loops in courses other than the research course) to retain these essential skills.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Cara&amp;aulast=Young&amp;atitle=Evidence-Based+Practice+Knowledge+Retention+Among+Nurse+Practitioner+Students&amp;stitle=Nursing+education+perspectives&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1097%2F01.NEP.0000000000001064&amp;title=Evidence-Based+Practice+Knowledge+Retention+Among+Nurse+Practitioner+Students&amp;volume=44&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=244&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Cara&amp;aulast=Young&amp;atitle=Evidence-Based+Practice+Knowledge+Retention+Among+Nurse+Practitioner+Students&amp;stitle=Nursing+education+perspectives&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1097%2F01.NEP.0000000000001064&amp;title=Evidence-Based+Practice+Knowledge+Retention+Among+Nurse+Practitioner+Students&amp;volume=44&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2023&amp;spage=244&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;
